Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploring the Role of Kin28/Cdk7 in Triggering Sequential Histone and Polymerase Modifications

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past decades, two major paradigms have emerged in the field of transcription regulation. The histone code hypothesis posits that different combinations of histone modifications define a code that is deciphered by different sets of histone-binding proteins. The sequential association of these proteins leads to further modifications of histones and these events play a key role in the regulation of gene transcription. Similarly, based on sequential modifications of the C-terminal domain (CTD) of RNA polymerase II, a CTD code hypothesis was proposed. This hypothesis links CTD modifications with the association of different protein complexes, which participate in promoter escape, transcription elongation, pre-mRNA processing, and transcriptional termination. The functional crosstalk between the two codes may be mediated by Kin28, a cyclin-dependent kinase that phosphorylates the CTD. In this project, a chemical-genomics approach will be used to investigate the role of Kin28 (Cdk7 in metazoans). In vivo inhibition of Kin28 by highly specific small molecules demonstrates that the kinase is not required for transcriptional initiation but may have more profound roles in pre-mRNA processing and chromatin remodeling. These novel roles of this kinase will be investigated through pursuing the following aims: 1: Does Kin28 prime the CTD code? and 2: Does Kin28 trigger sequential histone modifications?

The Ansari lab integrates chemical, genomic, biophysical, and molecular genetic approaches to probe intractable questions in eukaryotic gene transcription. Our results with chemical inhibition of Kin28 have led to re-evaluation of many models that were derived on the results with temperature sensitive alleles of this kinase. The Kin28ts alleles disrupt the stability of the multi-enzyme TFIIH complex and thus do not directly address the role of the kinase in various processes. This realization has had a tremendous impact on those who use temperature sensitive alleles of other components of the transcriptional machinery. These studies will enhance the understanding of the forces that govern various stages of the transcription cycle. Moreover, by collaborating with nanoengineering groups as well as with organic synthesis and computational genomics laboratories the Ansari lab is developing new tools to tackle challenging questions in biology. The collaborations expose engineers and statisticians to problems in biology. The rich interface between disciplines introduces students to new scientific concepts and fosters a multidisciplinary approach to scientific problems. Undergraduates and high school students are engaged in laboratory research to ensure that they develop projects that provide meaningful results and contribute to scientific understanding of gene expression. The composite impact of this project will be to explore new biological problems, expand the horizons of the students and colleagues that we work with, and provide powerful new tools to the broader scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Career grant support permited us to explore the role of kinases that control gene expression of nearly all genes in eukaryotic genomes.  We focused on Kin28, also known as Cdk7 in humans, because it is thought to be a key controller of the RNA polymerase II that is bound at promoters but dormant.  Action of Kin28/Cdk7 helps the polymerase transition into an actively transcribing enzyme.  Kin28 was thought to achieve this critical function by placing phosphate groups on the C-terminal domain (CTD) of the largest subunit of the polymerase.  The funded work successfully challenged this dogma and using a targeted chemical approach showed that the enzymatic function of Kin28/Cdk7 was not required for transcription initiation or elongation.

In the process we also developed genomic platformes that perimitted us to explore all the phosphate marks there were placed by other enzyme across all transcribing polymerase across entire genome.  Combining this genome-wide locator analysis with targeted chemical inhibition of other kinases that act on polymerase we were able to find how different enzyme were linked during the process of transcription.

Using this chemical-genomic approach along with the parallel analysis of all kinases that dwell in the cell's nucleus we found new functions for old kinases.  And, we found new marks (Ser7) on the CTD that revealed that these marks may control different classes of genes. The funded work changed our paradigms and work in baker's yeast yielded insights that were validated by us and other in human cells.

Broader Impact:

While performing this work we were able to engage nearly 20 undergraduates, 6 graduate students and 6 postdoctoral fellows in hands on scientific exploration of fundamental processes of life. We were also able to bring chemists, statisticians, engineers, biologists and physicians together to develop new technologies and concepts to tackle intractable problems.  We trained visiting scholars from Europe, Asia and Latin America.  And we hosted cross-disciplinary symposia on studying and synthesizing genetic circuits and cellular machines in living organisms. Finally, we developed several undergraduate training programs, such as the IGEM chapter of UW-Madison, the Khorana Program for the exchange of over a hundred American and Indian students and even sent food secuirty experts to remote areas of India to learn about sparse resource management.  The visits also benefited nearly 50,000 rural women and nearly five times as many people in one of the most impoverished areas of the world. This was a collateral benefit that was unanticipated and was cost neutral to the NSF.

Overall the five year, Career award, benefited many students an scholars as well as ordinary people on both sides of the globe.
